column2:
Who is that person?
----
사람 (saram) = person
• Generic word for "person"
• Can be modified: 한국 사람 (Korean person)

More examples:
• 좋은 사람 (good person)
• 저 사람 (that person over there)

I am a student.
----
학생 (haksaeng) = student
• Very common word
• 대학생 = university student

More examples:
• 학생이 많아요. (There are many students.)
• 저는 학생이에요. (I am a student.)

He/She is a teacher.
----
선생님 (seonsaengnim) = teacher
• Respectful term
• 님 is an honorific suffix

More examples:
• 선생님은 어디에 계세요? (Where is the teacher?)
• 한국어 선생님 (Korean language teacher)

My friend is a student.
----
친구 (chingu) = friend
• Close friend
• 남자친구/여자친구 = boyfriend/girlfriend

More examples:
• 친구가 많아요. (I have many friends.)
• 제 친구 (my friend)

My name is Daewon.
----
이름 (ireum) = name
• Noun

More examples:
• 이름이 뭐예요? (What's your name?)
• 당신의 이름은? (Your name?)

Korea is a good country.
----
나라 (nara) = country/nation
• Can refer to nation or state

More examples:
• 어느 나라 사람이에요? (What country are you from?)
• 우리 나라 (our country)

Korea is in Asia.
----
한국 (hanguk) = Korea / South Korea
• 대한민국 = Republic of Korea (formal)
• 한국어 = Korean language

More examples:
• 한국이 좋아요. (I like Korea.)
• 한국 사람 (Korean person)

I am American.
----
미국 (miguk) = America / United States
• Short for 아메리카
• 미국인 = American person

More examples:
• 미국은 크다. (America is big.)
• 미국 음식 (American food)

France is in Europe.
----
프랑스 (peurangseu) = France
• European country
• 프랑스어 = French language

More examples:
• 프랑스가 어디예요? (Where is France?)
• 프랑스 사람 (French person)

Japan is next to Korea.
----
일본 (ilbon) = Japan
• Neighboring country to Korea
• 일본어 = Japanese language

More examples:
• 일본 음식 (Japanese food)
• 일본 사람 (Japanese person)

The weather is good.
----
좋다 (jota) = to be good
• Descriptive verb (adjective)
• Can describe things, people, situations

More examples:
• 날씨가 좋아요. (The weather is good.)
• 사람이 좋아요. (The person is nice.)

The weather is bad.
----
나쁘다 (nappeuda) = to be bad
• Opposite of 좋다
• Used for things, behavior, situations

More examples:
• 사람이 나빠요. (The person is bad.)
• 날씨가 나빠요. (The weather is bad.)

The house is big.
----
크다 (keuda) = to be big
• Descriptive verb
• Size descriptor

More examples:
• 크다 → 커요 (polite)
• 집이 아주 커요. (The house is very big.)

The room is small.
----
작다 (jakda) = to be small
• Opposite of 크다
• Size descriptor

More examples:
• 작다 → 작아요 (polite)
• 방이 너무 작아요. (The room is too small.)

There are many people.
----
많다 (manta) = to be many/much
• Quantity descriptor
• Used for countable and uncountable

More examples:
• 친구가 많아요. (I have many friends.)
• 시간이 많아요. (There's a lot of time.)

There's little time.
----
적다 (jeokda) = to be few/little
• Opposite of 많다
• Quantity descriptor

More examples:
• 사람이 적어요. (There are few people.)
• 돈이 적어요. (There's little money.)

The book is new.
----
새롭다 (saeropda) = to be new
• Fresh, recent, modern
• 새 = new (modifier form)

More examples:
• 새로운 친구 (new friend)
• 책이 새로워요. (The book is new.)

The computer is old.
----
오래되다 (oraedoeda) = to be old (for things)
• NOT used for people (use 나이가 많다)
• Indicates age of objects

More examples:
• 집이 오래됐어요. (The house is old.)
• 책이 오래됐어요. (The book is old.)

Who is a student?
----
누구 (nugu) = who
• Question word
• Use with 이/가 in questions

More examples:
• 누구예요? (Who is it?)
• 저 사람이 누구예요? (Who is that person?)

What is this?
----
뭐 (mwo) = what (casual)
• Short for 무엇
• Very common in questions

More examples:
• 뭐예요? (What is it?)
• 뭐 해요? (What are you doing?)

Where is the school?
----
어디 (eodi) = where
• Location question word
• Use with 이/가

More examples:
• 어디예요? (Where is it?)
• 집이 어디예요? (Where is your house?)

This is a book.
----
이것 (igeot) = this thing / this
• Demonstrative pronoun
• Can be shortened to 이거 (casual)

More examples:
• 이것이 뭐예요? (What is this?)
• 이것은 제 것이에요. (This is mine.)

What is that?
----
그것 (geugeot) = that thing / that
• Demonstrative pronoun (near listener)
• Can be shortened to 그거 (casual)

More examples:
• 그것이 뭐예요? (What is that?)
• 그것은 책이에요. (That is a book.)

What is that (over there)?
----
저것 (jeogeot) = that thing over there
• Demonstrative pronoun (far from both)
• Can be shortened to 저거 (casual)

More examples:
• 저것은 학교예요. (That over there is a school.)
• 저것이 우리 집이에요. (That over there is our house.)

Here is a school. / This place is a school.
----
여기 (yeogi) = here / this place
• Location demonstrative
• Near speaker

More examples:
• 여기가 어디예요? (Where is this place?)
• 여기 앉으세요. (Sit here.)

Where is that place?
----
거기 (geogi) = there / that place
• Location demonstrative
• Near listener

More examples:
• 거기 좋아요? (Is it nice there?)
• 거기가 학교예요. (That place is a school.)

That place over there is our house.
----
저기 (jeogi) = over there / that place far away
• Location demonstrative
• Far from both speaker and listener

More examples:
• 저기 보세요! (Look over there!)
• 저기가 어디예요? (Where is that place over there?)

It's a good thing.
----
것 (geot) = thing
• Generic "thing"
• Very versatile noun

More examples:
• 먹을 것 (thing to eat / food)
• 좋은 것 (good thing)

Today's weather is good.
----
날씨 (nalssi) = weather
• Common topic of conversation
• Often used with 좋다/나쁘다

More examples:
• 날씨가 어때요? (How's the weather?)
• 날씨가 나빠요. (The weather is bad.)

Our house is small.
----
집 (jip) = house / home
• Can mean building or household
• 우리 집 = our home

More examples:
• 집에 가요. (I'm going home.)
• 집이 커요. (The house is big.)
